page.title: 10Fields, Woods and Hedgerows.
page.content: The woodlands throughout the area are planted with softwoods and hardwoods. The predominate species are chestnut, oak and cherry and a few other broadleaved varieties. The faster growing softwoods are interplanted for protection against bad weather and to encourage growth. Some parts of the area suffer from lack of soil and are susceptible to drought. Bracken and heather tend to be the only survivors in these areas. Varieties of wild orchids can be found in Hospital Wood near the A 417. The rare Star of Bethlehem flower can be seen growing on the roadsides near Bromesberrow School and in a few of the cottage gardens. The Malverns are a haven for naturalists. We discovered an enthusiast who had recorded sightings of 67 species of birds and 25 species of butterflies on Raggedstone Hill.
